newsitem.title: USA: Gymboree's profits flat after charge.
newsitem.headline: Gymboree's profits flat after charge.

text.p: Gymboree Corp. said Wednesday its fiscal first-quarter profits were virtually unchanged from a year ago after it took a one-time charge related to the departure of its chief executive in February.

The company, which makes and sells clothing and accessories for young children, said net income for the 13 weeks ended May 3 edged up to $8.60 million, or 34 cents a share, from $8.59 million, which also equalled 34 cents a share.

Gymboree, which offers parent-child developmental play programmes at some 375 franchised centres, said its latest results included an after-tax charge of 2 cents a share, or $510,000, related to the resignation of Nancy Pedot as president and CEO.
The company, which is based in Burlingame, Calif., did not offer any further details about the charge.
Without the charge, it said, net income would have risen by 7 percent to $9.2 million, or 36 cents a share.
Gymboree said its net sales jumped by 23 percent to $85.2 million from $69.1 million, although sales at stores opened at least one year grew by only 2 percent.

Gary White, who succeeded Pedot as president and CEO, said sales were affected by a general decline in retail sales after Easter, which resulted in higher April markdowns than the company had planned.
Gymboree's stock lost 62.5 cents to $22.875 in early afternoon trading on the Nasdaq market.
